channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Norway Returns a Rare Silent Film to China
item.description: A print of “The Cave of the Silken Web,” released in 1927, is believed to be the only existing copy of the film, which was directed by Dan Duyu and is based on an episode from the Chinese classic novel “Journey to the West.”
item.category: The Cave of the Silken Web (Movie)
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:credit: National Library of Norway, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A scene from the 1927 Chinese film "The Cave of the Silken Web."

item.title: Troubled Italian Bank May Seek Larger Share Sale
item.description: Monte dei Paschi will try to raise 5 billion euros instead of the expected €3 billion, Italian news reports said, sending shares lower.
item.category: Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Desalination Plant Proposed Near Beijing, Reports Say
item.description: The project could supply much of the capital’s drinking water by 2019, the state media reported, suggesting a major push to alleviate water shortages.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Ukraine Says It Has Begun Military Operation in East
item.description: After days of failing to enforce its own ultimatums to pro-Russia militants, the government established a checkpoint near the town of Slovyansk.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: F.B.I. Video Warns of Efforts to Recruit American Students as Spies
item.description: The bureau says it wants American students preparing to be able to recognize when they might be the targets of recruiting efforts by foreign intelligence agencies.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: European Parliament Approves Laws on Banking Overhaul
item.description: The directives come after the Continent’s debt crisis led Britain, Portugal and other countries to use public funds to bail out troubled lenders.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: India Ink: India’s Supreme Court Recognizes 3rd Gender
item.description: In a landmark ruling, the Supreme Court directed the central and state governments to give full legal recognition to transgender people.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Animal Rights Group to Turn Bear-Bile Farm into Sanctuary
item.description: More than 130 bears are to be turned over to the nonprofit Animals Asia Foundation by a state-owned company in China to be rehabilitated.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Bears waiting for food at a bear farm of Guizhentang Pharmaceutical, which makes tonics from bile extracted from the bears.

item.title: Pistorius Re-Enacts Moments After Girlfriend’s Shooting
item.description: Since last week, Oscar Pistorius has faced grueling interrogation by the prosecutor, who has accused him of lying, dissembling and changing his testimony.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arrived at court on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Military Newspaper Likens Lost Jet to Pearl Harbor
item.description: A commentary in the Liberation Army Daily sought to draw military lessons from the loss of Flight 370, citing the surprise 1941 attack by Japan that led America into World War II.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A Royal Australian Air Force plane flying past the British naval ship H.M.S. Echo as they searched for the missing Malaysia Airlines flight on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Death That Kindled the Uprising at Tiananmen Square
item.description: The death in 1989 of Hu Yaobang, a former general secretary of the Communist Party who had been accused of being too soft on student protests, became a vehicle for the Chinese public to voice discontent.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Students paying homage to Hu Yaobang in Tiananmen Square during his funeral at the Great Hall of the People on April 22, 1989.

item.title: Submersible’s First Scan for Jet Wreckage Is Cut Short
item.description: A safety mechanism halted the first deployment of an unmanned submersible in the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, officials said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: India Ink: Expatriate Indians Return Home to Have Their Say
item.description: This is the first parliamentary election in which Indian expatriates, also known as nonresident Indians, can vote in their home country.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Nonresident Indians arriving in their home state of Kerala on April 7 to vote in the country's parliamentary elections.

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 15
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Supporters of the Bharatiya Janta Party holding the party symbol during a rally addressed by Narendra Modi in Chennai, capital of the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, on Sunday.

item.title: In Ukraine’s East, Russians Are Blending Right In
item.description: A video showed a lieutenant colonel of the Russian Army taking control of Ukrainian policemen who seized a station in the eastern town of Horlivka, Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Pro-Russian militants stormed a police station on Monday in the city of Horlivka, near the Russian border.

item.title: Editorial: In the Middle East, Time to Move On
item.description: The United States has been fully committed to a two-state solution, but now it must devote its attention to other international challenges like Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Ukraine Falters in Drive to Curb Unrest in East
item.description: Ukraine’s failure to enforce its own ultimatums and its appeal to the United Nations to send peacekeepers laid bare a grim reality for the shaky government in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Pro-Russian activists seized a police building Monday in Horlivka, Ukraine, as protests against the government in Kiev grew.

item.title: With Ukraine Tensions Mounting, U.S. Weighs New Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: After a weekend of meetings, the White House was working on a list of new targets who would be barred from traveling to the U.S. or whose assets there would be frozen, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew, left, and his Ukrainian counterpart, Oleksandr Shlapak, signed a $1 billion loan guarantee.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Homicides Decline Near Border, Report Says
item.description: Murders in Mexico declined in 2013, and they decreased significantly in several cities near the border with the United States, according to a new report.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: U.N. Is Asked to Resolve Envoy’s Visa Dispute
item.description: Iran on Monday said it had complained to the United Nations over the refusal by the United States to grant a visa to its choice for ambassador, Hamid Aboutalebi.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Vietnam: Dissidents Freed Amid Trade Negotiations
item.description: Vietnam has released two high-profile dissidents, raising the number of democracy activists freed this month to three, officials said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 2 Pakistanis Suspected of Cannibalism After Head Is Found
item.description: The police arrested a man suspected of cannibalism after they found an infant’s head at his home, and they are searching for the man’s older brother.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI
item.media:description: Muhammad Arif, right, was arrested Monday after the police responded to complaints of a foul smell coming from his house.

item.title: Nigeria Blast Kills Dozens as Militants Hit Capital
item.description: A bombing that killed at least 71 people in the capital may indicate that the extremist group Boko Haram is stepping up efforts to destabilize state institutions.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Emergency workers at the scene of an explosion on Monday that killed at least 71 people in Abuja.

item.title: Israeli Officer Killed on Way to Seder in West Bank
item.description: An Israeli police officer was fatally shot and his wife and young son were wounded as they drove to a Passover Seder near the West Bank city of Hebron.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: São Paulo Journal: Immigrants Stir New Life Into São Paulo’s Gritty Old Center
item.description: Entrepreneurs from Africa, Asia and Spanish-speaking Latin America are starting up businesses alongside the squalor and social ills of a downtrodden district.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mélanito Biyouha operates a restaurant in São Paulo’s old center that specializes in African cuisine. She is part of a new wave of immigrants in the Brazilian megacity.
